div.a: Opportunities for Tutors and Aspiring Teachers at Match
Opportunities for Tutors and Aspiring Teachers at Match

div.h1: Match Charter Public School will be closed through the remainder of the school year.

h2.em: We will continue to closely monitor the Coronavirus situation and follow the guidance set forth by the Governor and public health officials. We will inform match staff and families of any new information as it becomes available.

div.class: sqs-block image-block sqs-block-image sqs-col-5 span-5 float float-right
image-block-outer-wrapper layout-caption-hidden design-layout-inline combination-animation-none individual-animation-none individual-text-animation-none

div.h2: most recent communication to the Match community from the executive director
match Community Day student & family messages
match middle school student & family messages

li.p: Thursday, March 26, 2020 (letter about cyberbullying)

div.h2: match HIGH school student & family messages

li.p: Friday, April 3, 2020 (including letter on remote learning grades and Q3 report cards)
Tuesday, March 31, 2020 (including DESE letters about remote learning)
Friday, March 27, 2020 (including letter about cyberbullying)

h2.strong: Food and Meal Resources for Families

div.p: In order to promote the Governor’s stay-at-home advisory, starting Monday, March 30th meals will only be distributed on Mondays and Wednesdays between 11:00 a.m. — 1:00 p.m. at Match Middle School. Families will be able to pick up multiple days’ worth of meals at a time. The address of the middle school campus is 215 Forest Hills Street, Jamaica Plain 02130. These meals are non-perishable and, for the sake of safety, will be picked up in a grab-and-go manner as described below.

li.p: If families are driving to pickup meals, we ask that you remain in your car with your windows up when you arrive, and a Match staff member will put the meal packages in your car trunk.
If you are walking to pickup meals, please follow the onsite staff’s directions to pickup the meal packages in the designated areas of the school parking lot.

p.em: If you have any questions about meal distribution, please reach out to David Steefel-Moore at

div.p: IMPORTANT: The City of Boston also has setup grab-and-go sites around the city to hand out meals to ALL school-aged children during the extended school closure. If it is more convenient for a Match family to pickup meals at one of these sites, please feel free to do so! See below for a map of all city-wide meal distribution sites. You also can find more information on the City of Boston website, including each site’s hours of operation.

li.p: For families who receive SNAP benefits, Expensify.org is offering a one-time deal of matching SNAP grocery purchases up to $50 per family. Click here for more information on this deal.

Covid-19 Mutual Aid Networks (local Boston communities have created lists of folks who need support, as well folks who have the capacity to support their neighbors through shopping, babysitting, cooking, storage, and much more. Click on your neighborhood’s mutual aid network to fill out a form with your needs or how you can support your neighbors.)
List of food resources by Boston neighborhood (Brigham & Women’s Falkner Hospital)

p.a: Free delivery for prescription drugs, courtesy of CVS

li.p: Special grocery store hours for seniors and people with compromised immune systems:
Stop and Shop: 6:00-7:30 am daily for those over the age of 60
Shaw's and Star Markets: 7:00-9:00 am on Tuesdays and Thursdays for senior citizens, pregnant women, and those with compromised immune systems
Market Basket: 5:30-7:00 A.M. daily for those over the age of 60
Whole Foods: 7:00-8:00 A.M. daily for those over the age of 60

Trader Joe’s: first hour of operation (8:00-9:00 A.M. or 9:00-10:00 A.M. depending on the store) for those over the age of 60 and customers with disabilities who may need additional assistance while shopping

div.p: Many residents in our neighborhood either run or work for small businesses, almost all of whom are facing a huge squeeze right now. If you have the resources, order takeout from local restaurants, many of which are still open. Check out the City of Boston’s list of restaurants.
div.h2: remote learning and academic supports for students
div.p: Communication about specific assignments and remote learning plans during the school closure will come from the Principal at your student’s campus. Please refer to their messages for more details!

li.p: For MCD families: Arts & Athletics resources
For OT students: list of at-home sensory diet/OT-related activities

p.a: Educational resources and information for families
Supporting Students’ Science Learning During COVID-19 School Closures
Resources for English Learners and Students with Disabilities

div.h2: Free educational resources for students and families

p.a: Khan Academy: suggested Daily Schedule and Resources
New York Times at home activities and lessons for kids (updated daily)

li.p: Girls Who Code (at-home activities)
Libby (free ebooks and audiobooks via library lending)
Audible (free audiobooks via Amazon)
Project Gutenberg (free ebooks)

p.a: PBS Kids: daily resources and activities

li.p: KidsPost (from The Washington Post)
Tween Tribune (from the Smithsonian Institution)
Storyline Online (YouTube channel of celebrities reading aloud children’s books)
Playworks (livestream of kids’ exercises 3x/day on Facebook)
Cosmic Kids Yoga (yoga, mindfulness and relaxation designed specially for kids aged 3+,)

p.a: 12 famous museums that offer virtual tours

li.p: Free virtual field trips (famous palaces, museums, aquariums, zoos, landmarks and much more!)

p.a: GoNoodle: movement and mindfulness exercises for kids
Duolingo: learn a new language for free!

li.p: Educational Resources for Students and Families (compiled by MA Dept. of Elementary and Secondary Education)

p.em: What is COVID-19, or the coronavirus?

div.p: The Coronavirus Disease 2019 or COVID-19 (formerly referred to as 2019 Novel Coronavirus or 2019-nCoV) is a new respiratory virus that was first identified in Wuhan, China in December of 2019.

li.p: The coronavirus can spread when: (1) an infected person coughs or sneezes on another, and (2) that other person then touches their own mouth, nose, or eyes and becomes contaminated with the virus. Coronavirus is not an airborne virus. It is spread through direct contact or through close contact with someone who is infected (within 6 feet for 15 minutes or more).

p.em: What are the common symptoms of the coronavirus?

li.p: Most people infected with the virus have relatively mild symptoms similar to the flu including fever, coughing, and difficulty breathing. Much rarer and generally only for people with compromised immune systems, experience a severe case of infection which can cause bronchitis, pneumonia, severe acute respiratory syndrome, kidney failure and even death.

p.em: What to do if you think you have coronavirus?

div.p: If you think that you may have coronavirus, stay at home from school and work. Call your health care provider immediately.

p.em: Where can I find more information about the virus?

div.p: More information is available from the Boston Public Health Commission (BPHC) and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). The BPHC also has COVID-19 factsheets available in the following languages:

li.p: English (information about the coronavirus)
Spanish (información sobre el coronavirus)
Portuguese (informações sobre o coronavírus)
Haitian Creole (enfòmasyon sou coronavirus la)
Chinese (关于冠状病毒的信息)
Vietnamese (thông tin về coronavirus)

div.h2: PLEASe continue following recommendations from public health officials
div.p: While there are currently no vaccines available to protect against this novel coronavirus infection, many of the things you do to help prevent colds and the flu can help protect you against other respiratory viruses, including COVID-19.

li.p: Wash your hands often with soap and warm water for at least 20 seconds, especially after coughing or sneezing. Click here to read the CDC’s guidelines for proper hand washing.
Use hand sanitizer that is at least 60% alcohol, if regular soap and water is not available for hand washing.
Avoid touching your eyes, nose, and mouth, as well as shaking hands, hugging, and other physical forms of interpersonal greetings to prevent the spread of germs.
Clean things that are frequently touched (like doorknobs, tables, and countertops) with household cleaning spray or wipes.
Cover your mouth when you cough or sneeze. Use a tissue or your inner elbow, not your hands.

Practice social distancing to limit the contact you have with people outside of your household. By decreasing the frequency with which people interact directly, it will help to limit the spread of the virus in communities.
Stay home if you are sick and avoid close contact with others.

This crisis, more than ever, reminds us of the importance of having full access to government resources during times of need. Ensuring everyone fills out the Census helps us get the maximum amount of dollars and representation in Congress.
Fill out the census here. It takes 5-10 minutes.
To learn more about why the census is important check out the City of Boston's site.

li.p: How to file for unemployment (Department of Unemployment Assistance)
This process can be done online at the DUA website. There is no need to physically go into the office.
DUA is holding "virtual town halls" to answer people's questions about this process. Learn more and sign up here.
For anyone who doesn’t qualify for unemployment benefits, direct them to Disaster Unemployment Assistance.
Information on the Coronavirus and Youth Sports (from The Aspen Institute’s Project Play)
